In most jurisdictions, classes or businesses that provide instruction or training in a variety of fields are exempt from paying sales tax on materials used in their operations. This is typically the case because classes are considered to be providers of "services" rather than "tangible personal property" (TPP), which is subject to sales tax.

For example, in California, the Sales and Use Tax Regulation states that "instruction or training in any subject matter... is not considered the sale or transferred of tangible personal property, and is therefore exempt from sales tax" (Regulation 1608(a)). Similarly, in New York, the Department of Taxation and Finance's Tax Bulletin states that "instruction or training in any subject matter... is not considered the sale or transferred of tangible personal property, and is therefore exempt from sales tax" (Tax Bulletin 906(1)).

However, it's important to note that this exemption may not apply to all types of classes or materials. For example, some states may consider classes that provide instruction in products that are intended for use or consumption as part of the instruction to be subject to sales tax. Additionally, some states may have specific rules or regulations regarding the application of the exemption to particular types of businesses or activities.

It's also worth noting that the laws and regulations regarding sales
answers: In most jurisdictions, both the goods (raw materials) and the service (class) are being "sold" to the customer, who is the end user and thus the sale is subject to sales tax. So, when your friend charges for the class, that $100 is subject to all applicable sales taxes for the jurisdiction and all parent jurisdictions (usually city, county and state). The teacher should not have to pay sales tax when they buy the flowers from the wholesaler; most jurisdictions charge sales tax on end-user purchases only. However, they are required to have some proof of sales tax exemption for the purchase, which normally comes part and parcel with the DBA or other business entity registration paperwork in most cities/states. prompt:

What is a negotiable security and how are they related to derivatives?[/INST]
pred:
A negotiable security is a financial instrument that can be transferred from one party to another through a negotiable instrument. These instruments are commonly used as a means of financing, such as loans or securities offerings, and they can be traded on financial markets. Examples of negotiable securities include commercial paper, certificates of deposit (CDs), and Treasury securities.

Negotiable securities are closely related to derivatives in that they can be used to derive value from an underlying asset or market condition. Derivatives are contracts whose value is derived from an underlying asset, such as a stock, bond, commodity, or currency. Negotiable securities, such as CDs, can be used to derive value from a interest rate, while derivatives such as option contracts can be used to derive value from changes in the price of the underlying asset.

For example, an investor may buy a negotiable CD with a fixed interest rate, knowing that the interest payments will be earned over a set period of time. The investor can then sell the CD on the secondary market, such as a bond exchange, and earn a profit if the interest rate has risen since the CD was issued. This is an example of "delta" trading, where the investor benefits from changes in the underlying interest rate.

Another example is a Treasury
answers: negotiability is a legal concept that permits free transfer of a security without the requirement of prior consent of the issuer.  that means the issuer must pay the current holder of the security, irrespective of who he is.  negotiability also protects a good faith buyer of the instrument from adverse ownership claims of purported prior holders of the instrument.  it is not related to "negotiating" the price or whatnot.  A negotiable security means the current owner does not have to be concerned about acquiring the asset via a bad chain of title b/c he can always assert that he is a "holder in due course" defense against such claims, and have absolute security in his ownership right over the asset.  securities and derivatives are different.  securities are transferrable instruments representing a direct claim on the issuer for the value of the security, whether debt or equity ownership.  derivatives are bilateral contracts, which can only be entered into with the consent of both parties, and can only be transferred by such consent.  derivatives represent a claim against the parties of to the derivative that depends on some economic reference which is outside of the financial condition of the two parties to the contract, such as interest rates, FX rates, commodity prices, etc.

4. No taxes on Interest: As mentioned earlier, the interest earned on a TFSA is not subject to income tax. This means that you won
answers: As to where the interest comes from: The same place it comes from in other kinds of savings accounts. The bank takes the money you deposit and invests it elsewhere, traditionally by lending it out to others (hence the concept of a "savings and loan" bank). They make a profit as long as the interest they give for "borrowing" from you, plus the cost of administering the savings accounts and loans, is less than the interest they charge for lending to others. No, they don't have to pay you interest -- but if they didn't, you'd be likely to deposit your funds at another bank which did. Their ideal goal is to pay as little as possible without losing depositors, while charging as much as possible without losing borrowers. (yeah, I know, typo corrected) Why do they get higher interest rate than they pay you? Mostly because your deposits and interest are essentially guaranteed, whereas the folks they're lending to may be late paying or default on those loans. As with any kind of investment, higher return requires more work and/or higher risk, plus (ususally) larger reserves so you can afford to ride out any losses that do occur.

When a company files for bankruptcy, the assets it owns are typically subject to liquidation, and their value is determined at the time of the bankruptcy filing, not according to their current value. This is true for both personal and business bankruptcies.

Under Chapter 7 bankruptcy, also known as a "liquidation" bankruptcy, the assets are sold off to pay creditors, and the proceeds are divided among them according to the priorities set forth in the bankruptcy laws. Any remaining assets are then turned over to the bankrupt estate to be distributed among creditors. The value of the assets at the time of the bankruptcy filing is typically the basis for determining what they can be sold for, not their current market value.

Under Chapter 11 bankruptcy, also known as a "reorganization" bankruptcy, the goal is to allow the business to continue operating while it restructures its debt. The assets of the business are not liquidated, but rather are used to fund the ongoing operations of the business and pay creditors over time. The current value of the assets is typically taken into account in determining what they can be used to fund the business and pay creditors.

Credit Card Purchase - 'it is the bank's money no[t] yours' ?[/INST]
pred:
When you use a credit card to make a purchase, it's important to understand that the money used to fund the transaction doesn't belong to you - it's actually the bank's money on loan to you. This is a common misconception among credit card users, but understanding the true nature of your purchase can help you manage your spending and pay back your debt more effectively.

Here's why it's the bank's money:

1. The bank extends credit: When you use a credit card, the bank extends credit to you by providing the funds for your purchase. This means the bank is loaning you the money until you repay it, usually with interest.
2. The bank sets terms: The bank sets the terms of your credit card agreement, including the interest rate, minimum payments, and other conditions. This gives them control over how you use the card and how you repay any debt you accumulate.
3. The bank bears the risk: If you don't repay the full balance on your credit card, the bank bears the risk of non-payment. This is why they may charge interest on outstanding balances or decline to issue credit cards to customers with a history of default.

It's important to understand that using a credit card doesn't give you an open checkbook - it's actually the bank's money on loan to

Your exact rights will vary by bank, but mostly they need to follow the guidelines set by the Credit Card company - and you do need to be a bit careful - if you received goods which were fake or a dispute arises you may be up for shipping the goods back to the merchant - and you have a limited - but reasonable time - in which to make the dispute. Be sure to check the boxes for any exemptions or deductions that you may be eligible for, and provide your updated personal information.

The under payment penalties will be figured out as part of you income tax return.  What you should have done when you discovered this was use the extra withholding line on the W4 to further increase your withholding. The nice thing about withholding is that you back load it and the IRS does not care.  The company has no liability here. pred:
Stock awards are given to corporate employees as a form of compensation, and they differ from monetary bonuses in several ways. The decision to offer shares instead of money is based on various factors. Here are the reasons why companies choose stock over cash:

1. Retention: Shares are valuable only if the company performs well financially; if employees own shares and the company does not do as well as anticipated, they may lose value. By providing equity to workers, companies can encourage retention by emphasizing the employees' connection with the overall corporate performance and success. It reinforces their incentive to stay with the company, especially during challenging economic times when layoffs are commonplace and other companies might be tempting to poach employees. It offers the added benefit of aligning incentives between workers, management, and the board to increase shareholder value concurrently, making equity more rewarding to shareholders. By tying employee incentives to the overall performance of the business, retention is strengthened, leading to increased morale and productivity. By providing equity to workers, companies can make certain that workers are invested in the company and have enough money on hand in the future to protect expenditure and risk-taking. This is especially important during times when companies have to make long-term investment choices or take measured risks that have uncertain outcomes.
2
answers: There are a few reasons, dependent on the location of the company.  The first, as you mentioned is that it means that the employee is invested in the companies success - in theory this should motivate the employee to work hard in order to increase the value of their holdings. Sometimes these have a vestment period which requires that they hold the stock for a certain amount of time before they are able to sell, and that they continue working at the company for a certain amount of time. The second, is that unlike cash, providing stocks doesn't come out of the companies liquid cash. While it is still an expense and does devalue the shares of other shareholders, it doesn't effect the daily working capital which is important to maintain to ensure business continuity. And the third, and this is for the employee, is tax reasons. In particular for substantial amounts. Of course this is dependent on jurisdiction but you can often achieve lower tax rates on receiving shares vs a cash equivalent sum, as you can draw out the money over time lowering your tax obligation each year, or other methods which aren't possible to look into now. Hope this helps.

If a put seller closes early, the impact on the buyer depends on various factors. Here are some possible outcomes:

1. The buyer may retain their investment: If the put seller closes early, the buyer may retain their investment, depending on the terms of the option contract. The buyer may have bought a call option giving them the right, but not the obligation, to sell the underlying asset at a predetermined price (strike price) within a specified time frame. If the sellerscloses early, the option expires worthless, and the buyer retains their initial investment, minus any premium paid.
2. The buyer may lose money: If the option expires early, and the market price of the underlying asset is above the strike price, the buyer may lose money on their investment. This is because they could have bought the asset cheaper if they held on until the option expired. The difference between the option price and the current market price represents a potential loss to the buyer.
3. The buyer may avoid further loss: If the option expires early, and the asset's price is falling, the buyer may avoid further loss byclosing early. By selling back their right early, the buyer can limit their potential loss to the original price paid for the option. This is particularly beneficial in markets where the
answers: An option is freely tradable, and all options (of the same kind) are equal. If your position is 0 and you sell 1 option, your new position in that option is -1. If the counterparty to your trade buys or sells more options to close, open, or even reopen their position afterwards, that doesn't matter to your position at all. Of course there's also the issue with American and European Options. European Options expire at their due date, but American Options expire at their due date or at any time before their due date if the holder decides they expire. With American Options, if a holder of an American Option decides to exercise the option, someone who is short the same option will be assigned as the counterparty (this is usually random). Expiry is after market close, so if one of your short American Options expires early, you will need to reopen the position the next day. Keep in mind dividends for slightly increased complexity. American and European Options do not in any way refer to the continents they are traded on, or to the location of the companies. These terms simply describe the expiry rules.

A public company, also known as a publicly traded company, can turn shares into cash through several ways:

IPOs are the first time the company issues shares to the public, while secondary offerings are when the company sells existing shares to the public. The company raises funds from these offerings by issuing new shares or selling existing ones.
2. Buyback programs: Public companies can also purchase their own shares from investors, known as share buybacks or stock repurchases. This is a strategy to increase the value of the remaining shares by reducing the number of outstanding shares in the market. The company uses its cash reserves or raises funds through debt to finance the buyback program.
3. dividend payouts: Public companies can also generate cash by distributing a portion of their profit to shareholders through dividends. The company decides on the dividend payout ratio and announces it to the shareholders. The shareholders receive cash according to the dividend payout ratio.
4. Mergers and Acquisitions (M&A): A public company may use M&A to turn shares into cash. The company may acquire other companies and pay for them with cash

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is high trading volume in a stock indicative of? Is high liquidity a good thing or a bad thing?[/INST]
pred:
High trading volume in a stock is a sign of increased market interest in the security, implying strong demand from investors to buy or sell the stock. High liquidity is a desirable trait in financial markets, reflecting the ease with which buyers and sellers can enter and exit positions without significantly influencing the asset's price. Here are some reasons why high trading volume is considered a positive indicator:

1. Market depth: When a stock has high trading volume, it indicates that there are numerous buyers and sellers participating in the market, providing liquidity to the security. This market depth makes it easier for investors to find counterparties to trade with, regardless of the time of day or market conditions.
2. Market efficiency: High volume suggests that price discovery is taking place more quickly and accurately, as there are more eyes viewing the security and adjusting prices based on changing market sentiment. This efficiency helps prevent price distortions and keeps the security fairly valued in the eyes of investors.
3. Trader confidence: With high trading volume comes greater investor confidence in the security. When many market participants are trading in a stock, they perceive it as a stable and reliable investment, more likely to outperform in the long term.
4. Information flow: Active trading volume implies that there is a constant flow of information and sentiment analysis influencing the security's price
answers: In general, liquidity is a good thing, because it means it is easy for you to buy or sell a stock.   Since high liquidity stocks have a lot of trading, the bid-ask spreads tend to be pretty low.  That means you can go into the market and trade easily and cheaply at just about any time.  For low liquidity stocks, the bid-ask spreads can get pretty high, so it can make it hard or expensive to get into or out of your trades. On the flip side, everyone pays attention to high liquidity stocks, so it's harder to get an edge in your trading.  For a company like Microsoft there are 30-50 full time analysts that cover them, thousands of professional traders and millions of investors in general all reading the same new articles and looking through the same financials as you.  But in low liquidity stocks, there probably aren't any analysts, a few professional traders and maybe a few thousand total investors, so it can be easier to find a good buy (or sell). In general, high liquidity doesn't mean that everyone is selling or everyone is buy, it just means everyone is trading.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Please explain: What exactly is a CDS or “Credit Default Swap”?[/INST]
pred:
Sure, I'd be happy to explain what a credit default swap (CDS) is!

A credit default swap (CDS) is a financial contract between two parties that provides protection against credit losses in the case of a borrower defaulting on their debt obligations. The buyer of the CDS makes a series of payments to the seller in exchange for a payment made by the seller in the event of default. CDSs are typically used to hedge against the risk of default by a bond issuer or a loan obligation.

Here's how CDS work:

1. The buyer of the CDS (the Protected Party) pays a premium to the seller (the Issuer) in exchange for coverage against credit losses.
2. The seller agrees to make payments to the Protected Party if the bond issuer or loan obligation defaulted.
3. The seller takes on the credit risk associated with the bond issuer or loan obligation, in return for the premium paid by the Protected Party.
4. The buyer of the CDS can then sell their bonds or loan obligations to the seller, who assumes the credit risk associated with those securities.
5. The buyer of the CDS can also use the contract as insurance to hedge against the potential loss of value of their bonds or
answers: A Credit Default Swap is a derivative, a financial contract with a value dependent upon another asset. A CDS, in essence, is exactly what it sounds like a swap upon default. The typical arrangement is that a holder of non-risk free credit enters into an arrangement with a counterparty to pay the counterparty a portion of the income received from the non-risk free credit in exchange for being able to force the counterparty to deliver risk free credit if the non-risk free credit defaults. Banks use this mechanism to reduce the risk of the loans they produce while packaging them to be resold to investors.  Banks will typically buy CDSes on mortgages and corporate bonds, paying part of the income from interest payments received, to have the right to force counterparties, typically hedge funds and insurance companies, to swap national Treasuries upon the event that the mortgages or corporates default.  The banks receive less income yet are able to take on more inventory to sell to investors so that more loans can be made to borrowers, households and corporations. Hedge funds typically take on more complex arrangements while insurance companies sell CDSes because they are usually overflowing with risk-free assets yet are starved for income.

Network marketing, also known as multi-level marketing (MLM), is a business model that involves recruiting and compensating distributors to sell products or services through a network of independent contractors. The key characteristic of network marketing is that the distributors earn income not only from their own sales but also from the sales of the people they recruit to join the network. This creates a hierarchical structure, with higher levels of compensation awarded to distributors who recruit more people and generate greater volume of sales.

Network marketing has gained popularity in recent years due to the potential for flexible and sustainable income, as well as the independence it offers to entrepreneurs and individuals looking to supplement their income. The industry is diverse, with products ranging from health supplements, cosmetics, and wellness products to technology and service-based offerings.

However, like any industry, network marketing has its critics and regulatory issues. Some critics argue that the model is not a sustainable business and is based on high-pressure tactics and overpriced products. Additionally, some governments have laws that restrict or regulate the industry to protect consumers and prevent pyramid schemes. It's important to note that not all network marketing companies are the same, and it's essential to do thorough research and vetting before joining any program.

They believe that the best investment returns are typically earned by those who are prepared to wait for many years.
